OverviewMy Name is Mayo is a short, click spam game where you click on a jar of mayo in order to uncover different stories told in one-liners that are also achievements. I will try to write this review as serious as possible, though... come on. This is meant to be a joke. (I hope!)

The Pros:It's a teeny bit fun - And by that I mean, it's so bad it's good. You get a chuckle during your first (an hopefully only playthrough)
Great Gag Gift - When this goes on sale, it's half a buck. Not even a real jar of mayo can't beat that price. Send them to your friends before you give them the actual gift.
Easy Achievements - Half an hour of clicking (I suggest making a click macro if you can, so as not to wear your mouse for no reason) and you get 50 easy achievements along with a perfect game!
Trading Cards - At this point, every stupid game on Steam has these. Let them idle so you can at least return your investment a bit.
Leaderboards?! - This actually has a Steam Leaderboard that ranks you based on how many times you've tapped the mayo jar. Some of these entries (although clearly illicit) show just what people can do out of boredom.
The Cons:It costs money - While one buck is not going to break the bank, I can't think of any reason to spend it on this. There are loads other even stupider games that go for free. Unless you're in for the achievements and / or trading cards, go elsewhere.
Could have been... longer? - Although I don't regret not being able to play this game more, it had the potential for the joke. Much more content could have been put in, even if it made it would make it in a cookie clicker clone.
Conclusion:Seriously now, I love myself some occasional $h!ts and giggles, but at some point you have to draw the line between what should be somewhere on Newgrounds with a donate button, and an actual game for sale on Steam. There's nothing wrong with this game (apart from everything) but Steam just is not the place for it.

reviewText:
Here is the not so heroic journey of trying to open one friggin' stubborn mayonnaise jar, presented as a clicker game full with sarcastic achievements. Uhm... Okay. I won this game in a giveaway and tried it out of pure curiosity to begin with, which doesn't serve me right most of the time. Writing a review for this one will be a challenge. I really should appreciate the way developers' mind work here. Even now I'm trying to get my head together to think about something imaginative to say about a mayonnaise jar, and as absurd it may be, some people managed to make a whole game out of it!

Ehm... My Name is Mayo is a clicker game - and aside not really being the most absurd one that I've ever seen in the market either, has a weird sense of humor targeting a selection of pop culture references wrapped in a vintage display. There is really nothing into it aside clicking on a mayonnaise jar while listening to the repetition of the same pesky 40s advertisement jingle tune. After a certain amount of clicking, you unlock short and absurd story paths for your mayonnaise jar and given the opportunity to dress it up in various accessories. As being the mission of any and all clicker games, your primary motivation here is to kill some brain cells while looking at your screen with empty eyes, silently drooling and clicking with your mouse to fill the illusion of you are actually doing something. Well done! It takes 10.000 clicks to collect all that there is within this game, never to visit again. If you are a strict achievement hunter and got it for an easy completion; sure, this is your game. You might consider running a script rather than actually clicking it through anyhow though.

Could I recommend it? Sure, why not if you strictly know what is it that you are getting here? I, myself prefer games with actual stories but also know first handedly the mindless therapeutic relaxation of being able to not think anything serious as a long time player of Clicker Heroes. My Name is Mayo is a perfect medium for that. The game deserves some appreciation for being humorous without being imposing, obnoxious or promising false depth anyhow. While we ponder on the philosophy, the boundless ethical and existential conflict hidden behind a mayonnaise jar, we keep clicking. Will we ever grasp the enlightenment?

reviewText:
TL;DR: Only gameplay is poking (clicking) a mayonnaise jar. Is this art or junk?

It is unfair to regard My Name is Mayo like a conventional game. Clearly it doesn't have gameplay as its main focus. It left me with a rather mixed feelings but having to choose, ultimately I'm leaning to the side of thumbs down.

Presented with a huge jar of Mayo (tm), you proceed to poke at it with the equally huge finger-shaped cursor. Click click click, poke poke poke. Is this supposed to be a thing? Since it's mostly sold in plastic tubes around here I don't have experience with real-life mayo jars.

There are no time limits nor arbitrary restrictions of other kinds: it's the epitome of casual.

Achievement unlocked!
It's basically an achievement dispenser. All cheevos have an in-game picture and associated text, which forms a short story or monologue, so they are integral to the story". To see the whole story
date: highlighting the picture will add some detail into the mayo jar (like a bra or a simple curious animation) and story will proceed when you click it again a bunch.\n\nGraphics are okay
recommended: music makes you hum along even if it's terribly repetitive. However
hoursPlayed: this extremely casual entertainment lasts only as long as it takes for you to click about 10000 times
voteText:
so likely just 30 to 60 minutes. Leaderboards for the highest clickers is basically a tongue-in-cheek joke.

What's the point?
So is it a good game? Definitely not. Is it fun or entertaining? Mildly. Is there a higher meaning to all of this? It is slightly thought-provoking to the point of being pointless. I am left with an irrational feeling of being mocked. Maybe that's the point. After all I just spent 45 minutes poking a mayonnaise jar.

To the very least it is really cheap and basically feeds you 50 "achievements" that for once don't feel like achievements."

reviewText:
TL;DR: Buy if you spare a dollar. Don't buy if you don't like clicker games.

Price\quality: This game takes about an hour to finish, the normal price of this game is a dollar. The legal American minimum wage is 7.50, it's 8.05 in my state. I have a job so this means that I can easily afford 8 of these games within an hour (taxes not included). Money is not an issue to me. I actually enjoyed this game. I liked that it had an ending. I don't have an issue with clicker games or meme games so that's a major influence in my review.

I enjoy clicker games to a certain extent. I recognized that this game wasn't going to last long, but the art style and the achievements made up for it (I got all the achievements!). It's only a dollar. What can you buy for a dollar? Not an actual mayo jar, nope. That costs at least 3 dollars where I live (*estimation, I'll update this review once I see the actual price in-store). A dollar won't get you that much.

For a dollar I had a lot of fun. I'm a Youtuber so playing this for my channel was honestly hilarious, I was laughing a bunch of times. I made a livestream of it and some people came to watch me, I'll put the video at the end for those who want to watch the highlights.

I started playing this game with a blank slate of what I was expecting. The only thing I knew was that someone made this game and tried to make it their product towards the world. I do this every day with my own videos, it's already difficult as is with the market saturation.

So does this game have enough originality to warrant a dollar? Yes. BUT. These are my personal preferences: I like story-driven games, I like games with endings, I have no issues with clickers, I like puns & memes, I love cats, I like mayo, art style in-game is a big plus for me and I liked the design of the pots and the achievements, there were no bugs for me while playing this game, I had no problems with recording, I like indie games and although there are other free games like this, still I can't blame someone for asking less than the price of a real mayo jar for something they worked longer than an hour for to make.

reviewText:
When you are subjected to a piece of art there are two things you must ask yourself: what is this piece trying to say, and what does it make me feel.

Throughout this game you experience the life of another. Their hopes and dreams, struggles with family and intimacy and finding one's self. This game carries a strong message; we are who we make ourselves.

Throughout the game you are rewarded, for the completion of mundane and banal tasks, brief glimpses into the main character's life. The games allows you to reflect upon yourself and attempts to guide you into the realization that it is only through experimentation and discovery that we can find our true selves.

We know what the game sets out to accomplish; what does it make us feel? I found myself profoundly changed after experiencing this game. I laughed, shuddered, got excited, leapt off my seat, and even wept. I feel that in the aftermath of this true piece of art there will come about a social change. I know that many, like myself, will have their view on life irrevocably altered.

I highly recommend this game and as such will give it a perfect score.
5/7 Can't wait for GOTY edition!
